blog.name: angelofberlin2000
blog.title: Like a Rose trampled on the ground
blog.description:
In addition to the pain and the exhaustion, he recalled how waiting on the cross between takes became tedious. To fight the boredom, he listened to music on headphones. One particular song called "Above All" (Like a Rose ...) by Michael W. Smith helped him through his most difficult moments.

"It arrived when I was confused and angry. I didn't think I could go on. The song described how Jesus was rejected and alone. That thought took me to a place — it opened an interior door that held me while on the cross," an emotional Caviezel explained. "The experience of feeling rejected and alone as all those around me laughed while drinking their hot coffees, oblivious to what was occurring. Jesus must have felt like this — forsaken, rejected, alone, and despised. It helped me pray in a very deep way — to pray without words, to pray from the heart. The discomfort, the loneliness, the split shoulder, the raw flesh all forced me into the arms of God because I had nowhere else to go for a performance I knew I was unable to create."
Jim Caviezel, Shamelessly Catholic

summary: THE B-LIST: 7 COMFORT FILMS THAT ARE GUARANTEED PICK-ME-UPS Whether you suffer from Seasonal Affective Disorder, general...
caption:
THE B-LIST: 7 COMFORT FILMS THAT ARE GUARANTEED PICK-ME-UPS

Whether you suffer from Seasonal Affective Disorder, general depression or are just feeling glum thanks to the constant grey, dreary, chilly weather these days, you might be in the need for a feel-good film and a cup of cocoa right about now. Allow me to help with a viewing list that’s guaranteed to lift your mood.

blog.name: the-flicks-are-all-right
blog.title: the flicks are all right
blog.description:
Astoundingly amateur LGBT movie reviews.

All of my reviews contain spoilers.

title: My Own Private Idaho (1991)
body:
Director: Gus Van Sant

Starring: River Phoenix, Keanu Reeves, William Richert, Udo Kier, James Russo, Flea

Rotten tomatoes score: 81%

*spoilers ahead*

It’s difficult to classify Gus Van Sant’s idiosyncratic third feature; part disengaged chronicle of the murky and the bizarre, part melancholic modern fairy tale that follows two Portland street hustlers, Mike (Phoenix) and Scott (Reeves), as they traverse life on society’s periphery. 

The film’s opening shot is an illuminated dictionary definition of the word, “narcolepsy”, saving some exposition when the subsequent scene ends with Mike lying, cataplectic, on a deserted highway.

It is through Mike’s eyes we see the first portion of the film, his narcoleptic episodes acting as missing reels that force you to experience the movie the same way Mike experiences the world. As an epileptic I can attest to Van Sant’s impressive accuracy in depicting the kind of dreamy dissociation with which you’re compelled to go through life when time is stitched together in ways that don’t always make sense.

By the time we reach Portland we’re already aware that Mike’s is a precarious existence that relies heavily on the decency of others (chiefly his best friend, Scott); an unlikely but touching theme in a film about homeless male prostitutes. His disparate encounters with clients are clouded in a subtle sense of foreboding but Mike seems, for the most part, to have an ingenuous trust in others.

A modern pseudo-adaptation of Shakespeare’s Henry IV part one and part two, Scott effectively serves as the film’s “Prince Hal”. The son of Portland’s mayor and soon to inherit a fortune - which his street friends seem to infer will be shared with them - he appears to have adopted this transient lifestyle largely to humiliate his father. Although he later explains to a Falstaff/Bukowski-esque character named Bob (Richert), with whom he shares an oblique father-son type of relationship, that his motives are a little more self-serving.

The closest thing to a plot comes later in the movie when Mike decides he wants to find his long-estranged mother, whose absence seems to have left him traumatised and with a quiet longing to be loved. Accompanied by Scott, their unsuccessful search takes them from Portland to Idaho to Italy and back. And their time on the road allows Mike a campfire confession of his unrequited love for Scott in the film’s most tender and well-acted scene.

At once taciturn yet heart-breakingly open, gentle but detached enough bear life’s injustices without self-pity Mike is ultimately a victim of circumstance. An extraordinarily dysfunctional family (in which it’s implied that his older brother (Russo) is also his father), and a penchant for falling asleep at the drop of a hat when experiencing intense emotions (sometimes played inappropriately for comic effect) have left him bereft and destitute.

His endearingly childlike expression of this: “if I’d had a normal family and a good upbringing, I would’ve been a well-adjusted person”, makes his apparent lack of resentment towards Scott’s privilege all the more affecting.

Scott’s later abandonment for an Italian girl with whom he fell in love on their journey leaves Mike adrift, floating beside the world rather than in it, his one remaining tether gone.

River Phoenix’s portrayal of Mike oozes with sincerity. You wonder, if not for his untimely death two years after making this film, he might have evolved into one of the greatest actors of his generation (his brother certainly did). And Keanu Reeves has never been better; his inscrutable Scott’s final humiliation of Bob and dismissal of his ephemeral street-self is upsetting mainly because of its inevitable ramifications on his friendship with Mike.

My Own Private Idaho’s ambiguous ending sees the film come full circle with Mike incapacitated on an empty highway, completing a gorgeous, flawed cinematic poem; an avant-garde meditation on loneliness and the universal need to belong, and a staple of queer cinema that makes Van Sant’s later, questionable efforts (the saccharine and overrated Good Will Hunting and the pointless Elephant, among others) all the more perplexing. 


Rating: ★★★★☆
